qtext: What is the range for the number of passengers a Boeing 747-400 airplane can carry?
atext: In common usage, the term "number" may refer to a symbol, a word, or a mathematical abstraction.

qtext: What is the range for the number of passengers a Boeing 747-400 airplane can carry?

qtext: What is the range for the number of passengers a Boeing 747-400 airplane can carry?

atext: As Paley grew more remote, he installed a series of buffer executives who sequentially assumed more and more power at CBS: first Ed Klauber, then Paul Kesten, and finally Frank Stanton.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Second only to Paley as the author of CBS's style and ambitions in its first half-century, Stanton was "a magnificent mandarin who functioned as company superintendent, spokesman, and image-maker".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: He had come to the network in 1933 after sending copies of his PhD thesis "A Critique Of Present Methods and a New Plan for Studying Radio Listening Behavior" to CBS top brass and they responded with a job.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: He scored an early hit with his study "Memory for Advertising Copy Presented Visually vs. Orally" which CBS salesmen used to great effect bringing in new sponsors.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1946, Paley named Stanton President of CBS and promoted himself to Chairman.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Stanton's colorful, but impeccable, wardrobe – slate-blue pinstripe suit, ecru shirt, robin's egg blue necktie with splashes of saffron – made him, in the mind of one sardonic CBS vice-president, "the greatest argument we have for color television".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS was also hit, though not as severely: Paley's brilliant 1928 affiliate contract which had given CBS first claim on local stations' air during sponsored time – the "network option" – came under attack as being restrictive to local programming.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Fly's panel also forbade networks from owning artists' representation bureaus, so CBS sold its bureau to Music Corporation of America and it became Management Corporation of America.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Even before hostilities commenced in Europe, one of the most played songs on radio was Irving Berlin's "God Bless America", popularized by CBS's own Kate Smith.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: His combined shows contributed as much as 12% of "all" CBS revenues; by 1948, he was pulling down a half-million dollars a year.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1947, Paley, still the undisputed "head talent scout" of CBS, led a much-publicized "talent raid" on NBC.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Capturing NBC's cornerstone show was "coup" enough, but Paley repeated in 1948 with longtime NBCers Edgar Bergen, Charlie McCarthy and Red Skelton, as well as former CBS defectors Jack Benny, radio's top-rated comedian, and Burns and Allen.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Paley achieved this rout with a legal agreement reminiscent of his 1928 contract that caused some NBC radio affiliates to jump ship and join CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS would buy the stars' names as a property, in exchange for a large lump sum and a salary.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The plan relied on the vastly different tax rates between income and capital gains, so not only would the stars enjoy more than twice their income after taxes, but CBS would preclude any NBC counterattack because CBS owned the performers' names.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As a result of this, Paley got in 1949 something he had sought for 20 years: CBS finally beat NBC in the ratings.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In the spring of 1940, CBS staff engineer Peter Goldmark devised a system for color television that CBS management hoped would leapfrog the network over NBC and its existing black-and-white RCA system.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The CBS system "gave brilliant and stable colors", while NBC's was "crude and unstable but 'compatible'".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Ultimately, the FCC rejected the CBS system because it was incompatible with RCA's; that, and the fact that CBS had moved to secure many UHF, not VHF, television licenses, left CBS flatfooted in the early television age.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Gradually, as the television network took shape, radio stars began to migrate to the new medium.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: When CBS announced in 1956 that its radio operations had lost money, while the television network had made money, it was clear where the future lay.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The retirement of Arthur Godfrey in April 1972 marked the end of the longform program on CBS radio; programming thereafter consisted of hourly news summaries and news features, known in the 1970s as "Dimension", and commentaries, including the "Spectrum" series that evolved into the "Point/Counterpoint" feature on the television network's "60 Minutes" and "First Line Report", a news and analysis feature delivered by CBS correspondents.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The network also continued to offer traditional radio programming through its nightly "CBS Radio Mystery Theater", the lone holdout of old-style programming, from 1974 to 1982.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The CBS Radio Network continues to this day, offering hourly newscasts, including its centerpiece "CBS World News Roundup" in the morning and evening, weekend sister program "CBS News Weekend Roundup", the news-related feature segment "The Osgood File", "What's In the News", a one-minute summary of one story, and various other segments such as commentary from Seattle radio personality Dave Ross, tip segments from various other sources, and technology coverage from CBS Interactive property CNET.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS is the last of the original Big Four radio networks still owned and operated by its founding company; ABC Radio was sold to Citadel Broadcasting in 2007 (and is now a part of Cumulus Media) while Mutual (now defunct) and NBC Radio were acquired by Westwood One in the 1980s (Westwood One and CBS were under common ownership from 1993 to 2007; the former would be acquired outright by Dial Global in October 2011).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS's involvement in television dates back to the opening of experimental station W2XAB in New York City on July 21, 1931, using the mechanical television system that had been more-or-less perfected in the late 1920s.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) issued permits to CBS and NBC at the same time and intended WNBT and WCBW to sign on simultaneously on July 1, so no one station could claim to be the "first".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Toward the end of the war, commercial television began to ramp up again, with an increased level of programming evident from 1944 to 1947 on the three New York television stations which operated in those years (the local stations of NBC, CBS and DuMont) But as RCA and DuMont raced to establish networks and offer upgraded programming, CBS lagged, advocating an industry-wide shift and restart to UHF for their incompatible (with black and white) color system; the FCC putting an indefinite "freeze" on television licenses that lasted until 1952 also didn't help matters.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Only in 1950, when NBC was dominant in television and black and white transmission was widespread, did CBS begin to buy or build their own stations (outside of New York) in Los Angeles, Chicago and other major cities.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Up to that point, CBS programming was seen on such stations as KTTV (channel 11) in Los Angeles, which CBS – as a bit of insurance and to guarantee program clearance in Los Angeles – quickly purchased a 50% interest in, partnering with the "Los Angeles Times" newspaper.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS then sold its interest in KTTV (which today is the West Coast flagship of the Fox network) and purchased outright Los Angeles pioneer station KTSL (channel 2) in 1950, renaming it KNXT (after CBS's existing Los Angeles radio property, KNX), later to become KCBS-TV.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1953, CBS bought pioneer television station WBKB in Chicago, which had been signed on by former investor Paramount Pictures (and would become a sister company to CBS again decades later) as a commercial station in 1946, and changed their call sign to WBBM-TV, moving the CBS affiliation away from WGN-TV.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: WCBS-TV would ultimately be the only station (as of 2013) built and signed on by CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The rest of the stations would be acquired by CBS, either in an ownership stake or outright purchase.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS would also temporarily return to relying on its own UHF technology by owning WXIX in Milwaukee (now CW affiliate WVTV) and WHCT in Hartford, Connecticut (now Univision affiliate WUVN), but as UHF was unviable at the time, CBS decided to sell those stations off and affiliate with VHF stations WITI and WTIC-TV (now WFSB), respectively.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: (Ironically, CBS would later be forced back onto UHF in Milwaukee due to the 1994 United States broadcast TV realignment; it is now affiliated with WDJT-TV in that market.)

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: More long-term, CBS bought stations in Philadelphia (WCAU, now owned by NBC) and St. Louis (KMOX-TV, now KMOV), but CBS would eventually sell these stations off as well; before buying KMOX-TV, CBS had attempted to purchase and sign on the channel 11 license in St. Louis, now KPLR-TV.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS did attempt to sign on a station in Pittsburgh after the "freeze" was lifted, as Pittsburgh was then the sixth-largest market but only had one commercial VHF station in DuMont-owned WDTV, while the rest were either on UHF (the modern-day WPGH-TV and WINP-TV) or public television (WQED).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Although the FCC turned down CBS's request to buy the channel 9 license in nearby Steubenville, Ohio and move the license to Pittsburgh (that station, initially CBS affiliate WSTV-TV, is now NBC affiliate WTOV-TV), CBS did score a major coup when Pittsburgh-based Westinghouse Electric (a co-founder of NBC with RCA) bought WDTV from struggling DuMont and opted to affiliate the now-rebranded KDKA-TV with CBS instead of NBC (like KDKA radio) due to NBC extorting and coercing Westinghouse to trade KYW radio and WPTZ (now KYW-TV) for Cleveland stations WTAM, WTAM-FM (now WMJI), and WNBK (now WKYC); the trade ended up being reversed in 1965 by order of the FCC and the United States Department of Justice after an eight-year investigation.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This coup would eventually lead to a much stronger relationship between Westinghouse and CBS decades later.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The "talent raid" on NBC of the mid-1940s had brought over established radio stars; they now became stars of CBS television as well.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: One reluctant CBS star refused to bring her radio show, "My Favorite Husband", to television unless the network would recast the show with her real-life husband in the lead.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1949, CBS offered the first live television coverage of the proceedings of the United Nations General Assembly.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This journalistic tour-de-force was under the direction of Edmund A. Chester, who was appointed to the post of Director for News, Special Events and Sports at CBS Television in 1948.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As television came to the forefront of American entertainment and information, CBS dominated television as it once had radio.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1953, the CBS television network would make its first profit, and would maintain dominance on television between 1955 and 1976 as well.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This success would continue for many years, with CBS bumped from first place only by the rise of ABC in the mid-1970s.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Perhaps because of its status as the top-rated network, during the late 1960s and early 1970s CBS felt freer to gamble with controversial properties like the "Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour" and "All in the Family" and its many spinoffs during this period.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Upon becoming commercial station WCBW in 1941, the pioneer CBS television station in New York City broadcast two daily news programs, at 2:30 and 7:30 p.m. weekdays, anchored by Richard Hubbell.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The national emergency even broke down the unspoken wall between CBS radio and television.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As CBS wrote in a special report to the FCC, the unscheduled live news broadcast on December 7 "was unquestionably the most stimulating challenge and marked the greatest advance of any single problem faced up to that time".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: On May 3, 1948, Douglas Edwards began anchoring "CBS Television News", a regular 15-minute nightly newscast on the rudimentary CBS television network, including WCBS-TV.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The NBC television network's offering at the time "NBC Television Newsreel" (premiering in February 1948) was simply film with voice narration.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The broadcast was renamed the "CBS Evening News" when Walter Cronkite replaced Edwards in 1962.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Edwards remained with CBS News with various daytime television newscasts and radio news broadcasts until his retirement on April 1, 1988.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Although CBS Television was the first with a working color television system, they lost out to RCA in 1953, due in part because the CBS color system was incompatible with existing black-and-white sets.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Although RCA, then-parent company of NBC, made its color system available to CBS, the network was not interested in boosting RCA's profits and televised only a few specials in color for the rest of the decade.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS would later show two other versions of the ballet, a semi-forgotten one-hour German-American version hosted by Eddie Albert, shown annually for three years beginning in 1965, and the well-loved Baryshnikov production from 1977 to 1981 (this production later moved to PBS).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Beginning in 1959, "The Wizard of Oz", now telecast by CBS as a family special in its own right (after the cancellation of "Ford Star Jubilee"), became an annual tradition on color television.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: However, it was the success of NBC's 1955 telecast of the musical "Peter Pan", starring Mary Martin, the most watched television special of its time, that inspired CBS to telecast "The Wizard of Oz", "Cinderella" and "Aladdin".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: From 1960 to 1965, CBS Television limited its color broadcasts to only a few specials such as "The Wizard of Oz", and only then if the sponsor would pay for it.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Red Skelton was the first CBS host to telecast his weekly programs in color, using a converted movie studio, in the early 1960s; he tried unsuccessfully to persuade the network to use his facility for other programs, then was forced to sell it.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: One famous CBS Television special made during this era was the Charles Collingwood-hosted tour of the White House with First Lady Jackie Kennedy.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Beginning in 1963, at least one CBS show, "The Lucy Show", began filming in color at its star and producer Lucille Ball's insistence; she realized that color episodes would command more money when they were eventually sold into syndication, but even it was broadcast in black and white through the end of the 1964–65 season.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This would all change by the mid-1960s, when market pressure forced CBS Television to add color programs to the regular schedule for the 1965–66 season and complete the changeover during the 1966–67 season.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: By the fall of 1967, nearly all of CBS's television programs were in color, as were NBC's and ABC's.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1965, CBS telecast a new color version of Rodgers and Hammerstein's "Cinderella".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1967, NBC outbid CBS for the rights to the annual telecast of "The Wizard of Oz" and the film moved to NBC.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: However, the network quickly realized their mistake in allowing what was then one of its prime ratings winners to be acquired by another network, and by 1976, the film returned to CBS, where it remained through the end of 1997.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS showed it twice in 1991, in March and again the night before Thanksgiving.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: By the end of the 1960s, CBS was broadcasting virtually all of its schedule in color, but many of its shows (including "The Beverly Hillbillies", "Mayberry R.F.D.", "Petticoat Junction", "Hee Haw" and "Green Acres") were appealing more to older and more rural audiences and less to the young, urban and more affluent audiences that advertisers sought to target.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: While the "rural" shows got the axe, new hits, like "The Mary Tyler Moore Show", "All in the Family", "The Bob Newhart Show", "Cannon", "Barnaby Jones", "Kojak" and "The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour" took their place and kept CBS at the top of the ratings through the early 1970s.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: One of CBS's most popular shows at that time was "M*A*S*H", a dramedy based on the hit Robert Altman film.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: It was viewed by nearly 106 million Americans (77% of viewership that night), which established it as the most watched episode in American television history, a record which stood until the broadcast of Super Bowl XLIV in 2010, also on CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Silverman also first developed his strategy of spinning new shows off an established hit while at CBS, with "Rhoda" and "Phyllis" spun from "The Mary Tyler Moore Show", "Maude" and "The Jeffersons" spun from "All in the Family" and "Good Times" from "Maude".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: After Silverman's departure, CBS dropped behind ABC in the 1976–77 season, but still rated strongly, based on its earlier hits and some new ones: "One Day at a Time", "Alice", "Lou Grant", "WKRP in Cincinnati", "The Dukes of Hazzard" (suspiciously "rural") and, the biggest hit of the early 1980s, "Dallas".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: By 1982, ABC had run out of steam, NBC was in dire straits with many failed programming efforts greenlighted by Silverman during his 1978 to 1981 tenure there, and CBS once more nosed ahead, courtesy of "Dallas" (and its spin-off "Knots Landing"), "Falcon Crest", "Magnum, P.I.", "Simon & Simon" and "60 Minutes".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS also broadcast the popular NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament every March beginning in 1982 (taking over for NBC).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS had gone deeply into debt as a result of a failed effort by Ted Turner to take control over CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The battle was headed by CBS chairman Thomas Wyman.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS sold its St. Louis station KMOX-TV and allowed the purchase of a large portion of its shares (under 25 percent) by Loew's Inc. chairman Lawrence Tisch.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: By the end of the 1987-88 season, CBS had fallen to third place for the first time, behind both ABC and NBC, and had some major rebuilding to do.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS was also still getting decent ratings from "60 Minutes", "Dallas" and "Knots Landing".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Under network president Jeff Sagansky, the network was able to get strong ratings from new shows "", "Touched by an Angel", "Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman", "Walker, Texas Ranger", and a resurgent "Jake and the Fatman" during this period, and CBS was able to reclaim the first place crown briefly, in the 1992–1993 season, though its demographics skewed older than ABC, NBC or even Fox, with its relatively limited presence at that time.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: However, CBS would soon suffer a major blow in a move that would change American television forever.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1993, the fledgling Fox network outbid CBS for the rights to broadcast games from the National Football League, resulting in several stations switching to Fox; CBS bore the brunt of the switches, since many of the network's existing affiliates switched to Fox (especially those owned by New World Communications, which Fox struck its largest affiliation deal with) and most of the stations CBS ended up with once its former affiliates switched to Fox were former Fox affiliates and independent stations, most of which had limited to no local news presence prior to joining CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The loss of the NFL, along with an ill-fated effort to court younger viewers, led to a drop in CBS' ratings.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Still, CBS was able to produce some hits, such as "Cosby", "The Nanny", "Cybill", "The King of Queens", "Becker", "Yes, Dear", and "Everybody Loves Raymond", and would regain the NFL (taking over the American Football Conference package from NBC) in 1998.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Another turning point for CBS came in the summer of 2000 when it debuted the summer reality shows "Survivor" and "Big Brother", which became surprise summer hits for the network.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In January 2001, CBS debuted the second season of the former show after its airing of the Super Bowl and scheduled it on Thursdays at 8 p.m. ET, and moved the police procedural "" (which had debuted that fall on Fridays at 9 p.m. ET) to Thursdays at 9 p.m. ET and was both able to chip away at and eventually beat NBC's Thursday night lineup, and attract younger viewers to the network.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS has had additional successes with police procedurals "Cold Case", "Without a Trace", "Criminal Minds", "NCIS", "The Mentalist", and "Person of Interest", along with "CSI" spinoffs ' and ', and "Hawaii Five-0" as well as sitcoms "Everybody Loves Raymond", "The King of Queens", "Becker", "Yes, Dear", "Still Standing", "Two and a Half Men", "How I Met Your Mother", "The New Adventures of Old Christine", "Rules of Engagement", "Two Broke Girls","The Big Bang Theory", and "Mike & Molly".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: However, according to Nielsen, CBS has been the top-rated network every season since then.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The two networks, being the most watched among all broadcast networks during the decade 2000s, tend to nearly equal one another in the 18–34, 18–49, and 25–54 demographics, with either CBS or Fox alternating in winning such demographics areas by very close margins.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Additionally, until 2012, CBS ranked in second place among adults 18-49, but after Fox's ratings declines during that year's fall season, the network was able to take the top spot in the demographic as well as in total viewers (for the fifth year in a row) by the start of 2013.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: When the 2012-2013 season ended, the tenth season of "NCIS" took the top spot in the most-watched shows of the year, which gave CBS its top rated show after "American Idol" ended its eight-year nationwide primetime lead and "NBC Sunday Night Football" took over the year before and year after.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Prior to the 1960s, CBS's acquisitions had been related mainly to its broadcasting business; these had included American Record Corporation and Hytron.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: During the 1950s and early 60's, CBS operated a CBS-Columbia division, manufacturing phonographs, radios, and televisions; but had problems with product quality and was not successful in that field.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1955, CBS purchased Terrytoons Inc., the animated cartoon studio, from its founder Paul Terry, not only acquiring Terry's backlog of cartoons for the network but continuing the studio's ongoing contract to provide theatrical cartoons for 20th Century Fox well into the 1960s.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: During the 1960s, CBS began an effort to diversify, and looked for suitable investments.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This and other acquisitions led to a restructuring of the corporation into various operating groups and divisions; the quality of the products coming out of these acquired companies was extremely lower, hence the term "pre-CBS" (meaning higher, sought after quality) and "CBS" (mass-produced lower quality).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In other diversification attempts, CBS would buy (and later sell) sports teams (especially the New York Yankees baseball club), book and magazine publishers (Fawcett Publications including "Woman's Day", and Holt, Rinehart and Winston), map-makers, toy manufacturers (Gabriel Toys, Child Guidance, Wonder Products, Gym Dandy and Ideal), and other properties.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS developed an early home video system called EVR (Electronic Video Recording,) but was never able to launch it successfully.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: By the mid-1980s, the investor Laurence Tisch had begun to acquire substantial holdings in CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Eventually he gained Paley's confidence, and with his support took control of CBS in 1986.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: When CBS faltered, underperforming units were given the axe.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1986, Tisch also shut down the CBS Technology Center in Stamford, which had started in New York City in the 1930s as CBS Laboratories and evolved to be the company's technology research and development unit.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Columbia Records was a record label owned by CBS starting in 1938.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1962, CBS launched CBS Records International to market Columbia recordings outside of North America, where the Columbia name was controlled by others.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1966, CBS Records was made a separate subsidiary of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS sold the CBS Records Group to Sony in 1988, initiating the Japanese buying spree of U.S. companies (such as MCA, Pebble Beach Co., Rockefeller Center and the Empire State Building) that continued into the 1990s.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The record label company was rechristened Sony Music Entertainment in 1991, as Sony had a short term license on the CBS name.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS Corporation formed a new record label named CBS Records in 2006.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS entered the publishing business in 1967 by acquiring Holt, Rinehart & Winston, who published trade books, textbooks, and the magazine "Field & Stream".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The next year, CBS added the medical publisher Saunders to Holt, Rinehart & Winston.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1971, CBS acquired Bond/Parkhurst, the publisher of "Road & Track" and "Cycle World".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS greatly expanded its magazine business by purchasing Fawcett Publications in 1974, bringing in such magazines as "Woman's Day".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS sold its book publishing businesses in 1985.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS exited the magazine business by selling the unit to its executive Peter Diamandis.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Encouraged by outraged Fender fans, CBS Musical Instruments division executives executed a leveraged buyout in 1985 and created Fender Musical Instruments Corporation.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: At the same time, CBS divested itself of Rodgers, along with Steinway and Gemeinhardt, all of which were purchased by Steinway Musical Properties.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS made a brief, unsuccessful move into film production in the late 1960s, creating Cinema Center Films.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This profit-free unit was shut down in 1972; the distribution rights to the Cinema Center library today rest with Paramount Pictures for home video (via CBS Home Entertainment) and theatrical release, and with CBS Television Distribution for television syndication (most other ancillary rights remain with CBS).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Yet ten years later, in 1982, CBS took another try at the film industry, in a joint venture with Columbia Pictures and HBO called TriStar Pictures.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Despite releasing such box office successes as "The Natural", "Places in the Heart", and "", CBS felt the studio was not making a profit and in 1985, sold its stake in TriStar to Columbia Pictures' then-owner The Coca-Cola Company.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 2007, CBS Corporation announced its intent to get back into the feature film business, slowly launching CBS Films and hiring key executives in the spring of 2008 to start up the new venture.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The name CBS Films was actually used once before in 1953, when it was briefly used for CBS's distributor of off-network and first-run syndicated programming to local television stations in the United States and internationally.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS entered into the home video market, when joined with MGM to form MGM/CBS Home Video in 1978, but the joint venture was dissolved by 1982.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS joined another studio: 20th Century Fox, to form CBS/Fox Video.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS's duty was to release some of the movies by TriStar Pictures under the CBS/Fox Video label.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS entered the video game market briefly, through its acquisition of Gabriel Toys (renamed CBS Toys), publishing several arcade adaptations and original titles under the name "CBS Electronics", for the Atari 2600, and other consoles and computers, also producing one of the first karaoke recording/players.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS Electronics also distributed all Coleco-related video game products in Canada, including the ColecoVision.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS later sold Gabriel Toys to View-Master, which eventually ended up as part of Mattel.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: About 20 former CBS affiliates switched to the rapidly rising Fox Television Network in the mid-1990s, while many television markets across the United States (KDFX in Palm Springs, California and KECY in Yuma, Arizona reportedly the first to switch in August 1994) lost their CBS affiliate for awhile.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS ratings were acceptable, but the network struggled with an image of stodginess.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS lost many longtime affiliates owned by New World Communications to Fox during the 1994 United States broadcast TV realignment.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Therefore, CBS tried to woo longtime ABC affiliates WXYZ-TV in Detroit and WEWS-TV in Cleveland (the former was actually an ABC O&O from 1948-1986, while the latter was a CBS affiliate from 1947-1955) in order to replace departing affiliates WJBK and WJW-TV, respectively.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: (CBS wound up affiliating with former Fox affiliate WOIO in Cleveland while purchasing little-known independent WGPR-TV in Detroit, now WWJ-TV.)

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Included in the deal was Baltimore NBC affiliate WMAR-TV (which had been affiliated with CBS from 1948-1981), displacing longtime ABC affiliate WJZ-TV, despite the fact that WJZ-TV, owned by Westinghouse Electric Corporation, had long dominated the Baltimore market while WMAR-TV had long been in a distant third and even nearly lost its broadcast license in 1991.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1994, Westinghouse signed a long-term affiliation deal to affiliate all five of its Group W TV stations with CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: While WJZ-TV and WBZ-TV switched to CBS in January 1995, the swap was delayed in Philadelphia when CBS discovered that an outright sale of channel 10 would have forced it to pay massive taxes on the proceeds from the deal.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: To solve this problem, CBS, NBC and Group W entered into a complex ownership/affiliation deal in the summer of 1995.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: NBC traded KCNC-TV in Denver and KUTV in Salt Lake City to CBS in return for WCAU, which for legal reasons would be an even trade.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS then traded controlling interest in KCNC and KUTV to Group W in return for a minority stake in KYW-TV.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As compensation for the loss of stations, NBC and CBS traded broadcasting facilities in Miami, with NBC-owned WTVJ moving to channel 6 and CBS-owned WCIX moving to channel 4 and becoming WFOR-TV.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1995, Westinghouse acquired CBS outright for $5.4 billion.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As one of the major broadcasting group owners of commercial radio and television stations (as Group W) since 1920, Westinghouse sought to transition from a station operator into a major media company with its purchase of CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Westinghouse's acquisition of CBS had the effect of suddenly turning the combined company's all-news radio stations in New York (WCBS and WINS) and Los Angeles (KNX and KFWB) from bitter rivals to sister stations.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Also that year, Westinghouse began the CBS Cable division by acquiring two existing cable channels from Gaylord Entertainment Company (The Nashville Network (now Spike) and Country Music Television) and starting a new one (CBS Eye on People, which was later sold to Discovery Communications).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS also owned CBS Telenoticias, a Spanish-language news network.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Following the Infinity purchase, operation and sales responsibilities for the CBS Radio Network was handed to Infinity, which turned management over to Westwood One, a company Infinity managed.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: For a time, CBS Radio, NBC Radio Networks and CNN's radio news services were all under the Westwood One umbrella.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: , Westwood One continues to distribute CBS radio programming, but as a self-managed company that put itself up for sale and found a buyer for a significant amount of its stock.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Also in 1997, Westinghouse changed its name to CBS Corporation, and corporate headquarters were moved from Pittsburgh to New York City.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1999, CBS paid $2.5 billion to acquire King World Productions, a television syndication company whose programs included "The Oprah Winfrey Show", "Jeopardy!"

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: By the end of 1999, all pre-CBS elements of Westinghouse's industrial past (beyond retaining rights to the name for brand licensing purposes) were gone.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: By the 1990s, CBS had become a broadcasting giant, but in 1999 entertainment conglomerate Viacom – a company that ironically was created by CBS in 1952 as CBS Films, Inc. to syndicate old CBS series and was spun off and renamed Viacom in 1971 – announced it was taking over its former parent in a deal valued at $37 billion.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Coincidentally, Viacom had bought Paramount Pictures, which had once invested in CBS, in 1994.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS became the center of a new company, CBS Corporation, which included the broadcasting elements, Paramount Television's production operations (now known as CBS Television Studios), UPN (which later merged with Time Warner's The WB into The CW), Viacom Outdoor advertising (renamed CBS Outdoor), Showtime Networks, Simon & Schuster, and Paramount Parks, which the company sold in May 2006.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As a result of the Viacom/CBS corporate split, as well as other acquisitions over recent years, CBS (under the moniker CBS Studios) owns a massive film and television library spanning nine decades; these include not only acquired material from Viacom and CBS in-house productions and network programs, but also programs aired originally on competing networks.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Shows and other material in this library include "I Love Lucy", "The Honeymooners", "The Twilight Zone", "Hawaii Five-O" (both the original and current remake), "Gunsmoke", "The Fugitive", "The Love Boat", "Little House on the Prairie" (U.S. television rights only), "Cheers", "Becker", "Family Ties", "Happy Days" and its spin-offs, "The Brady Bunch", "Star Trek", "The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles" (distribution rights on behalf of copyright holder Lucasfilm), "Evening Shade", "Duckman", "" and its spin-offs, the CBS theatrical library (including "My Fair Lady" and "Scrooge"), and the entire Terrytoons library from 1921 forward, amongst others.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Both CBS Corporation and the new Viacom are still owned by Sumner Redstone's company, National Amusements.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As such, Paramount Home Media Distribution (formerly Paramount Home Entertainment) continues to handle DVD and Blu-ray distribution for the CBS library.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: ACNielsen estimated in 2003 that CBS can be seen in 96.98% of all American households, reaching 103,421,270 homes in the United States.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS has 204 VHF and UHF owned-and-operated or affiliated stations in the United States and U.S. possessions.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS is also carried on cable television across Canada, via its U.S.-based affiliates, as well as in Bermuda, via local affiliate ZBM-TV.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: WKMG is a Graham Media CBS television station.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: From the 1940s to 1951, CBS Television used an oval spotlight on the block letters "C-B-S" for its logo.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The present-day Eye device was conceived by William Golden based on a Pennsylvania Dutch hex sign as well as a Shaker drawing (while commonly attributed to Golden, there is speculation that at least some design work on the symbol may have been done by another CBS staff designer, Georg Olden, one of the first African-Americans to attract some attention in the postwar graphic design field).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The following season, as Golden prepared a new "ident", CBS President Frank Stanton insisted on keeping the Eye device and using it as much as possible (Golden died unexpectedly in 1959, and was replaced by one of his top assistants, Lou Dorfsman, who would go on to oversee all print and on-air graphics for CBS for the next 30 years).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The CBS eye is now an American icon.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The logo is alternately known as the "Eyemark", which was also the name of CBS's domestic and international syndication divisions in the mid-to-late 1990s before the King World acquisition and Viacom merger.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The eye logo has frequently been copied or borrowed by television networks around the world.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Through the years, CBS has developed several notable image campaigns, and several of the network's most well-known slogans date from the 1980s.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: 1981's "Reach for the Stars" used a space-themed campaign to capitalize on both CBS's stellar improvement in the ratings and the historic launch of the space shuttle Columbia.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: 1982's "Great Moments" juxtaposed scenes from classic CBS programming such as "I Love Lucy" with scenes from the network's then-current classics such as "Dallas" and "M*A*S*H".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: From 1983 to 1986, CBS (by now firmly atop the ratings) featured a campaign based on the slogan "We've Got the Touch".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The 1986–87 programming season ushered in the "Share the Spirit of CBS" campaign, the network's first to completely use computer graphics and DVE effects.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The success of that campaign led to the 1987–88 "CBS Spirit" (or "CBSPIRIT") campaign.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Most CBS Spirit promos utilized a procession of show clips once again.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The announcement "THIS IS CBS" (Over the graphic of the famous CBS EYE) was done by television announcer Don Robertson then voice talent George Sheldon, and then by Charlie Van Dyke before the voice announcement was dropped in 1989.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: For the 1988–89 season, CBS unveiled its new image campaign, officially known as "Television You Can Feel", but more commonly identified as "You Can Feel It On CBS".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: However, it was this season in which CBS began its ratings freefall, the deepest in the network's history.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS ended the decade with "Get Ready for CBS".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The 1989–90 version was a very ambitious campaign that attempted to elevate CBS out of last place (among the major networks); the motif was network stars interacting with each other in a remote studio set, getting ready for photo and TV shoots, as well as for the new season on CBS.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The high-energy promo song and the campaign's practices saw many variations across the country as every CBS affiliate participated in it, as per a network mandate.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Also, for the first time in history, CBS became the first broadcast network to team with a national retailer to encourage viewership, with the CBS/Kmart Get Ready Giveaway.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The early 1990s featured less-than-memorable campaigns, with simplified taglines such as "This is CBS" (1992) and "You're On CBS" (1995).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Eventually, the advertising department gained momentum again late in the decade with "Welcome Home to a CBS Night" (1996–1997), simplified to "Welcome Home" (1997–1999) and succeeded by the spin-off campaign "The Address is CBS" (1999–2000).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Throughout the first decade of the 21st century, CBS's ratings resurgence was backed by their "It's All Here" campaign, and their strategy led, in 2005, to the proclamation that it was "America's Most Watched Network".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The network's 2006 campaign uses the slogan "We Are CBS", with the voice of Don LaFontaine.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: , the network has shifted to a campaign entitled "Only CBS" in which the network proclaims several unique qualities it has.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 2011, CBS returned to the usage of "America's Most Watched Network".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In October 2011, CBS celebrated 60 years of using the Eye logo.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Especially during the 1960s, the three major networks, NBC, CBS and ABC, would show elaborate promos during the summer months of their upcoming fall schedule of that year.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1961, CBS took the unusual step of airing a program entitled "CBS Fall Preview Special: Seven Wonderful Nights", using, not the usual television voiceovers, but stars of several CBS shows to promote the upcoming shows, stars such as Ed Sullivan ("The Ed Sullivan Show"), Rod Serling ("The Twilight Zone"), and Raymond Burr and Barbara Hale ("Perry Mason").

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As of 2013, CBS provides a schedule of 87½ regular weekly hours of network programming.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS News programming includes "CBS This Morning" from 7:00–9:00 a.m. weekdays and Saturdays; nightly editions of "CBS Evening News" (whose weekend editions are occasionally subject to abbreviation or preemption due to sports telecasts overrunning into the program's timeslot), the Sunday political talk show "Face the Nation", early morning news programs "Up to the Minute" and "CBS Morning News" and the newsmagazines "60 Minutes", "CBS News Sunday Morning" and "48 Hours".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Due to the unpredictable length of sporting events, CBS will occasionally delay scheduled primetime programs to allow the programs to air in their entirety (this is particularly prevalent on Sunday evenings during the NFL season, on weeks when CBS is scheduled to broadcast a late afternoon game).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS's daytime schedule is the home of the long-running game show "The Price Is Right".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As of 2012, CBS is the only network still producing daytime game shows.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Notable daytime game shows that once aired on CBS include "Match Game", "Tattletales", "The $10/25,000 Pyramid", "Press Your Luck", "Card Sharks", "Family Feud", and "Wheel of Fortune".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS games that also aired in prime time include "Beat the Clock", "To Tell the Truth" and "Password".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS introduced a new talk show titled "The Talk" on October 2010.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: , CBS Daytime airs two daytime soap operas each weekday: the hour-long series "The Young and the Restless" and the half-hour series "The Bold and the Beautiful".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS has aired the most soap operas of the Big Three television networks.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: After "Guiding Light" ended in September 2009, ABC overtook CBS as the network with the most daily hours dedicated to soap operas.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS reclaimed this distinction in January 2012, after ABC cancelled two of its three remaining soap operas.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Other than "Guiding Light", notable daytime soap operas that once aired on CBS include "As the World Turns", "Love of Life", "Search for Tomorrow", "The Secret Storm", "The Edge of Night" and "Capitol".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS broadcast the live action series "Captain Kangaroo" on weekday mornings from 1955 to 1982, and on Saturdays through 1984.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: From 1971 to 1986, the CBS News department produced one-minute "In the News" segments broadcast between other Saturday morning programs.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Otherwise, in regards to children's programming, CBS has aired mostly animated series for children, such as reruns of "Mighty Mouse", "Bugs Bunny" and "Tom and Jerry" cartoons, as well as the original version of "Scooby-Doo", "Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids", "Jim Henson's Muppet Babies", "Garfield and Friends", and "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1997, CBS began broadcasting "Wheel 2000" (a children's version of the syndicated game show "Wheel of Fortune"), and was broadcasting it simultaneously with the Game Show Network.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In September 1998, CBS began contracting out to other companies to provide programming and material for its Saturday morning schedule.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The first of these special blocks was "CBS Kidshow", which featured programming from Canadian studio Nelvana.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: It aired on CBS Saturday mornings from 1998 to 2000, with shows such as "Anatole", "Mythic Warriors," "Rescue Heroes" and "Flying Rhino Junior High".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 2000, CBS's deal with Nelvana ended, and the network then entered into a deal with Nickelodeon (owned by CBS's former parent company Viacom, which at one time was a subsidiary of CBS) to air its Nick Jr. programming under the banner "Nick Jr. on CBS".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: From 2002 to 2005, Nick's non-preschool series aired on it as well, under the name "Nick on CBS".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 2006, after the Viacom-CBS split, CBS decided to discontinue the Nick Jr. lineup and entered into a three-year agreement with DIC Entertainment (which was later assumed by the Cookie Jar Group after it acquired DiC that year), which included distribution of selected Formula One auto races on tape delay.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The "KOL Secret Slumber Party on CBS" premiered in September of that year; in the inaugural lineup, two of the programs were new shows, one aired in syndication in 2005 and three were pre-2006 shows.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In mid-2007, KOL withdrew sponsorship from CBS's Saturday morning block and the name was changed to "KEWLopolis".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Complimenting CBS's 2007 lineup was "Care Bears", "Strawberry Shortcake", and "Sushi Pack".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: On February 24, 2009, it was announced that CBS renewed its contract with Cookie Jar for another three seasons, through 2012.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: On July 24, 2013, CBS entered into an agreement with Litton Entertainment (which already programs a syndicated Saturday morning block exclusive to ABC stations) to launch a new Saturday morning block featuring live-action reality-based series.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The Litton-produced "CBS Dream Team" block, which is aimed at teenagers 13 to 16 years old, debuted on September 28, 2013, replacing "Cookie Jar TV".

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS was the original broadcast network home of the animated primetime holiday specials based on the comic strip "Peanuts", beginning with "A Charlie Brown Christmas" in 1965.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Over 30 holiday Peanuts specials (each for a specific holiday such as Halloween) were broadcast on CBS from that time until 2000, when ABC acquired the broadcast rights.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS also aired several primetime animated specials based on the work of Dr. Seuss (Theodor Geisel), beginning with "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" in 1966, as well as several specials based on the comic strip "Garfield" over the course of the 1980s (which led to Garfield getting his own Saturday morning cartoon on the network, "Garfield and Friends", from 1988 to 1995).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer", produced in stop motion by the Rankin/Bass studio, has been another annual holiday staple of CBS since 1972, but that special originated on NBC in 1964.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: As of 2011, "Rudolph" and "Frosty the Snowman" are the only two pre-1990 animated specials remaining on CBS; "Charlie Brown" and "The Grinch" moved to ABC, while cable network ABC Family owns the "Garfield" specials.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: All of these animated specials, from 1973 to 1990, began with a fondly remembered opening animated logo (about seven seconds long), which showed the words "A CBS Special Presentation" in colorful lettering (the ITC Avant Garde typeface, widely used in the 1970s, was used for this logo).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The word "SPECIAL", in all caps and repeated multiple times in multiple colors, slowly zoomed out from the frame in a spinning counterclockwise motion against a black background, and rapidly zoomed back into frame as a single word, in white, at the end; the logo was accompanied by a jazzy yet majestic up-tempo fanfare with dramatic horns and percussion (which was edited incidental music from the CBS crime drama "Hawaii Five-O", titled "Call to Danger" on the Capitol Records' soundtrack LP).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This opening sequence appeared immediately before the beginning of all CBS specials of the period (such as the Miss USA pageants and the annual Kennedy Center Honors presentation), in addition to animated ones (this opening was presumably designed by, or under the supervision of, longtime CBS creative director Lou Dorfsman, who oversaw print and on-air graphics for CBS for nearly 30 years, replacing William Golden, who died in 1959).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS was also responsible for airing the series of "Young People's Concerts" conducted by Leonard Bernstein.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: Over the years, CBS has broadcast three different productions of Tchaikovsky's famous ballet "The Nutcracker" – two live telecasts of the George Balanchine New York City Ballet production in 1957 and 1958 respectively, a little-known German-American filmed production in 1965 (which was subsequently repeated three times and starred Edward Villella, Patricia McBride, and Melissa Hayden), and beginning in 1977, the Baryshnikov staging of the ballet, starring the Russian dancer along with Gelsey Kirkland – a version that would become a television classic, and remains so today.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In April 1986, CBS presented a slightly abbreviated version of "Horowitz in Moscow", a live piano recital by legendary pianist Vladimir Horowitz.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The program was shown as an episode of "CBS News Sunday Morning" (televised at 9:00 a.m. in the U.S., as the recital was performed simultaneously at 4:00 p.m. in Russia).

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: It was so successful that CBS repeated it a mere two months later by popular demand, this time on videotape, rather than live.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In later years, the program was shown as a stand-alone special on PBS, and the current DVD of it omits the Charles Kuralt commentary, but includes additional selections not heard on the CBS telecast.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In 1986, CBS telecast "Carnegie Hall: The Grand Reopening" in primetime, in what was now a rare move for a commercial broadcast network, since most primetime classical music specials were relegated to PBS and A&E by this time.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: In order to compete with NBC, which produced the now-legendary televised version of the Mary Martin Broadway production of "Peter Pan", CBS responded with "Cinderella", with music by Richard Rodgers and a book and lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein II.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: It was originally broadcast live in color on CBS on March 31, 1957 as a vehicle for Julie Andrews, who played the title role; that broadcast was seen by over 100 million people.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: It was subsequently remade by CBS in 1965; that version starred Lesley Ann Warren, Stuart Damon, Ginger Rogers and Walter Pidgeon among others, and added a new song, "Loneliness of Evening", which had been composed for "South Pacific" in 1949 but not sung in that musical.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: This version was rebroadcast several times on CBS into the early 1970s, and is occasionally broadcast on various cable networks to this day.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: CBS was also the original broadcast home for the primetime specials produced by the National Geographic Society.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: The Geographic series in the U.S. started on CBS in 1964, moved to ABC in 1973, shifted to PBS (produced by WQED, Pittsburgh) in 1975, then to NBC in 1995, and returned to PBS in 2000.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
atext: A majority of the specials were narrated by various actors, notably Alexander Scourby during the CBS run.

qtext: What does "CBS" (television network) stand for?
